awd_titl_txt: Development of High-Purity NaI(T1) Crystals for the SABRE Dark Matter Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of normal atoms, but must be otherwise undetected elementary "dark matter" particles that do not emit or absorb light. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays. Detection of WIMP dark matter would solve a fundamental mystery in particle physics and cosmology, providing a unique window to learning about the primary matter constituent of the Universe and of physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. SABRE (Sodium-iodide with Active Background REjection) is an experiment that will search for dark matter signals using an array of Sodium Iodide (NaI) scintillating crystals. This award will provide funds to demonstrate the feasibility of fabricating ultra-low background NaI crystals, with lower levels of Potassium-40 and other radioactive impurities, by improving the methods to produce and purify NaI powder, and by developing methods to grow crystals with very low contamination of radioactive elements. 

The SABRE project provides ample opportunities for students and postdoctoral researchers to gain experience and training for careers in basic research. SABRE has promoted strong relationships with commercial companies and assisted in the development of special products available to all customers. These collaborations have brought improved high purity products and sensitive assay services to the market. The development of high purity NaI crystals is also making possible other new experiments with scintillating bolometers for dark matter research.

The sensitivity of the search for rare dark matter events depends critically on the background in the detector, which in NaI(Tl) crystals is dominated by low levels of K-40 radioactivity in the crystal. This award will support on-going development of NaI(Tl) crystals with lower intrinsic radioactivity. In addition, by coupling efficient low background photomultipliers to the crystals and reducing dynode afterglow with lower PMT voltage, they will achieve a threshold energy lower than that of the DAMA experiment. Their goal is a flat background of  ~ 0.10 cpd/kg/keV and a threshold energy less than 1 keVee.  Measurements of K at the level of 10 ppb have been possible for some time; an improvement to 2 ppb is indicated in recent work. A preliminary measurement of U and Th at a level of ~­ 0.5 ppt is indicated in recent work. These measurements are much faster than growing crystal and gamma counting and are thus guiding research in a timely way toward production of crystals with low levels of these radioactive impurities.

por.por_cntn:
The SABRE project aims to produce ultra-low background NaI(Tl) scintillating detectors to carry out a model-independent search for dark matter through the annual modulation signature, with an unprecedented sensitivity to confirm or refute the DAMA/LIBRA claim. The ultimate goal of SABRE is to operate two independent NaI(Tl) crystal arrays located in the northern (SABRE North) and southern (SABRE South) hemispheres to identify possible contributions to the modulation from seasonal or site-related effects.

As a large fraction of the background in the 1-6 keV energy region of interest (ROI) for dark matter search comes from radioactive contaminants in the crystal themselves, most notably 40K, 87Rb, 210Pb, and 3H, SABRE North carried out an extensive R&D on the production of ultra radio-pure NaI(Tl) crystals. To keep the intrinsic contaminants at a very low level, SABRE first developed a method to obtain ultra-pure NaI powder and then, a clean procedure to grow NaI(Tl) scintillating crystals. Techniques for the purification of NaI powder were investigated in collaboration with Sigma-Aldrich. This has led to the production of the so-called AstroGrade powder, which is now the standard powder used in NaI-based low background experiments. The NaI(Tl) crystals growth procedure instead, was developed in collaboration with Radiation Monitoring Devices, Inc. (RMD). Two different crystals, named NaI-31 and NaI-33, were successfully grown using the Vertical Bridgman method. The optimum crucible composition, together with a precision cleaning, showed no increase of the impurity levels in the crystals with respect to the starting powder.

The two crystals were characterized into the SABRE Proof-of-Principle (PoP) setup at the Gran Sasso National Laboratory (LNGS), in Italy. This setup consists of a low radioactivity copper detector module, composed by a NaI(Tl) crystal directly coupled to two high quantum efficiency and low background Photomultiplier Tubes (PMTs), installed inside a cylindrical stainless steel vessel filled with about 2 tons of liquid scintillator and instrumented with ten PMTs for active background rejection. The steel vessel is then protected from the environmental radioactivity of the experimental hall by an external passive shielding made of lead, polyethylene, and water.

Direct counting of beta and gamma ray signals with the SABRE PoP, has demonstrated very low internal radioactivity for the crystal NaI-33. By exploiting coincidences between the 3.2-keV X-rays/Auger electrons in the crystal and the 1.46 MeV gamma ray in the liquid scintillator veto, caused by the electron capture decay of 40K, it was possible to evaluate the natK contamination in the crystal. It resulted to be lower than 4.7 parts per billion (ppb) at 90% CL, which is the lowest level ever achieved in NaI(Tl) crystals. 

The measured background rate in the 1-6 keV ROI is 1.20 +/- 0.05 count/day/kg/keV. This represents a breakthrough result in the panorama of ultra-low background NaI(Tl) detectors for dark matter searches. Indeed, for the first time, a crystal with a background level comparable to that of DAMA/LIBRA crystals wa produced (see Fig.1).

The liquid scintillator veto was initially proposed to effectively reduce the 40K background from a predicted contamination of natK at the level of 10-20 ppb. Through the so-called PoP-dry setup, SABRE demonstrated that, with a radio-purity similar or below that of NaI-33, it is possible to achieve a background level in the ROI equally low with a purely passive shielding only, namely without the use of a liquid scintillator veto. The average background rate in the 1-6 keV ROI measured for the NaI-33 crystal within the PoP-dry setup is 1.35 ? 0.02 count/day/kg/keV, comparable with that obtained with the PoP setup. Such result demonstrates that, as the vetoable crystal internal contaminants (e.g. 40K) are low enough, the active veto is no longer necessary in order to tackle the challenge of obtaining a background rate equal or lower than 1 count/day/kg/keV.

Study of the purification of NaI powder by zone refining, carried out in collaboration with the Mellen Company, demonstrated that 40K can be further reduced, together with 87Rb, no longer constituting a worrisome background in the search for dark matter with NaI(Tl) detectors. This was not the case for intrinsic 210Pb instead, which, to date, remains one of the leading background for NaI(Tl) crystals in the ROI for dark matter searches, and further investigations on the powder purification are needed for its reduction. However, by using a combination of zone refining and low background methods developed for crystal NaI-33, we estimate that the overall background rate  in 1-6 keV energy range would be reduced to a rate lower than ~0.3 cpd/kg/keV.
